38807147.review: I have nearly 12 hours of gameplay but like a true idler, I was asleep through much of the mid-game. If getting down to it, there is probably 3-4 hours of gameplay here. It seems to be a one and done type game, but for 25-33¢ per hour, it was worth the cost. Pretty decent humor in the game and the bonus is that at the 90 minute mark, the game reminds you that you can still seek a refund. This type of game isn't for everyone and it's nice to see the dev recognize that.

38804773.review:
For the price, this is a fun little game that you'll probably play through once and be done with it.

It has a very light story of sorts, and I had a smile on my face as I finished it.

The reason I felt compelled to write a review is that the game warned me that 2 hours were approaching, in the event that I wanted to refund it. I thought that was a nice touch.

The game could have very easily latched on to the loot box hubbub and crapped out something cheap, but this felt like a bit of care and heart was put into it. Much more than the price might suggest.

If you like idle/clicker games and you want something to kill a couple of hours, I would say you can't go wrong with Loot Box Quest.

38768138.review:
Basically a perfect game. There's great humor, some min/maxing gameplay, and it's over in a few hours. It sets you back a dollar plus tax, and is worth that amount.

The complete lack of graphics works out fine, as a player you stop caring quickly. The written humor and the balanced progression are entertaing enough for most of us. There's also this ripped from the headlines feeling right now. Where the industry has been moving towards unethical monetization, and we're still trying figure out where to draw the line. That's when some of the joke's start sounding kind of plausible. 7/10. (DLC Quest was better.)

38728021.review:
Do you like clicker/idler games?  Do you like satire concerning the current state of the gaming industry?  If so, this is the game for you.

Pros:

-Cheap
-Easy to understand interface
-Lots of moving numbers to distract young children
-Amusing status updates and upgrades that are a vicious and easily understood satire of many modern game publishers and the terrible nature of the gaming market today
-Easy to acquire all achievements

Cons:

-If you play it without automating certain things, like with clicker macros (Automation is great!) you may have a sore finger and cause extra wear to your mouse buttons
-Not that much replayability

Pro and Con:

-Short

Conclusion:

A short, clicker/idler containing satirical commentary on the state of the gaming industry.  If you're keeping up with the news and trends in gaming, you'll both smile and cry a little bit inside with each upgrade or comment.  For 99 cents this game provided enough enjoyment in terms of its meaning and message, not its graphical content.  A low impact game where I think the developer earned the money paid.

38584515.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Loot Box Quest is a fun little clicker that has an actual ending, and the premise of the game is, you guessed it, loot boxes... Not sure what else you expected from this game really...

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
So, what can you expect from Loot Box Quest that isn't already shown in the trailer? Well really that is all that the game has to offer, and that's by no means a bad thing. Considering that the game is basically a parody of Loot boxes (*cough* probably something to do with EA's Starwars Battlefront 2 loot box system *cough*) it portrays what it wants to in the time that you put into the game, and considering that there is actually an end to the game there is a goal to reach to make you keep playing. 

For a clicker game it's adds a slight bit of complexity more near the end game, but obviously things start off slow like in most clicker games. As you progress the game makes you upgrade your gear, making automation possible to help get money faster, pretty standard for most clicker games. As you progress you will start creating your own games to make money, and will slowly start adding micro-transactions to your games. This is where the complexity starts to go up a bit, you have to pay devs to make your game analysts to improve the next game you create. You'll have to manage how many you hire, the more you hire the higher their cost will be but the faster they will create games/improve upon your next game. It makes for some interesting game play, being slightly strategic about how many you hire, although not at all that difficult. 

Eventually you'll get to the point where you will build your own company and have to manage your budget, what percentage of the budget goes into what category, and the assets which is what you need to upgrade further. A small nitpick I had was when this new mechanic was introduced nothing was really explained, only took a few minutes to figure out what everything did, but I would've liked a small explanation on what each budget percentage did.  Eventually you ill get to the end, maybe in like 3 - 4 hours and if you're feeling very adventurous then you could complete it in one sitting, but I would recommend coming back to it every now and then throughout a day or two.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Clicker games seemed to be divided into two different categories, those that are humorous but simplistic art style, or those with decent graphics and even though this one has simplistic graphics it's humour defiantly makes up for it. The layout of everything looks very clean, nothing too fancy but at the same time is still easy to look at and doesn't overload you with numbers of information about the game.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Generally the in-game music is a bit annoying in my opinion after playing it for a while, but there's always an option to turn it off, and even better you can listen to the music you have on steam to play in-game so that's pretty neat. Don't really see a lot of games do that nowadays

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Great parody game about loot boxes
+ Great complexity that goes slightly beyond normal clicker games
+ The game has a great humour throughout
+ Simplistic graphics
+ Custom Steam music that you own can be played in-game

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Nearer the end, the game doesn't really help you all that much with how key performance indicators work, although after a few minutes of analysing what each indicator percentage

[h1]Result / Final Thoughts[/h1]
Loot Box Quest is a great little clicker game that is funny, has simplistic graphics and can be completed in a day or so. For the price it's asking for, I think it's defiantly worth it, but hey even if you don't like it the developer tells you after playing the game for 90ish minutes that you can refund it if your not enjoying it. A gem of a game, highly recommended, even if it's for sh*ts and giggles.

[quote]For more reviews on indie to AAA games, go and follow [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/_YoloArmy]Yolo Amry[/url] [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6095538/]curator group here[/url]. Whether you do or don't, thanks for reading my review.[/quote]

38556906.review: One of the funniest idle games I've played with clever jokes and observations about the games industry. An excellent choice among the dollar tier games.

38548778.review:
Great, well written, incremental with surprisingly deep structure, great pacing, and an enjoyable meta-commentary on the state of gaming.

Especially given the low price of the game the unfolding mechanics are deeper and have more layers than I would have expected. The ending is rewarding enough and evokes a bit of a Paperclips-but-loot-boxes feel.

Like most incrementals it's not a 'hard' game and not progressing, while technically possible, is easily avoided. The pacing makes it a fun experience with shifting paradigms every 15 to 45 minutes. It goes through more than five distinct stages of gameplay and each is thought out and well designed. Most incrementals have the draw of doing something else and coming back to the game every once in a while. Loot Box Quest will keep you actively clicking and managing for the first hour or so and then let you wait more towards the end.

In total, the game takes around 3 hours to complete and the only real replay value is finishing off some achievements that can be missed along the way.

Having played shorter, more story focused, incrementals like "A Dark Room", "Paperclips" or "Spaceplan" and more long-running mechanicals ones like "Kittens", "Trimps", "Factory/ReactorIdle", "Realm Grinder" and "Sharks" this one definitely falls towards the side of a tightly paced, finish-in-one-sitting experience but has a comparable level of polish to the early versions of those games. 

It's a new entry for my short list of incrementals to recommend to people that might not be too familiar with the genre and a wholehearted recommendation.

38488000.review:
I'm a bit on the fence about this one. It's not bad as an idle game. There are chances to apply strategy, but they're pretty straight forward and don't require a lot of thought.

The big problem I have with it is that you can't buy loot boxes. The whole premise of the game is that loot boxes cost money, and it takes a lot to unlock the main character, so you go to extreme lengths to earn tons of money just to unlock him. But if you can't buy loot boxes then you're just making money for the sake of making money. I know it's a silly detail, but since the gameplay is a bit lacking the story has to kinda make up for it, and given that fundamental flaw it's just kinda weak.

Also the game doesn't remember that I turned the music off which is annoying. It's just a drum loop and I don't care to hear it.

Regardless the game is entertaining enough for the price. So I recommend.

38306704.review: Wonderful game. Looks good, plays good, funny, minimalistic, and gets it's message across. I most especially enjoy how no matter how far you go, your original goal sits there. it's not even meaningful profit anymore, but... there's one thing you want to get. One thing that means more to you than all of the money in the world. And it's the last thing you should even want, especially after having made it so far. Oh, and one more thing: I suggest getting the Little Inferno Soundtrack and playing the first track while you play this. The song fits great even if you never played Little Inferno. If you have played it, it'll feel like a match made somewhere so perfect it makes Heaven look like Hell.

38301286.review: Obviously kind of riding on the coattail of the EA disaster, but a surprisingly fun idler. In 90 minutes the mechanics change multiple times rather fundamentally. 38300496.review: I feel like clicker games should either have attractive graphics, complex systems or be funny. This is one of the funny ones. It looks and plays like a basic clicker game but it has amusing barbed comments about the video game industry. Unlike many other clicker games it also has no premium currencies or anything of the sort. Interestingly, after the 90 minute mark you get a message reminding you're still eligible for a refund if you feel like the experience wasn't worth that one dollar you spend. That's one honest dev right there.

38296147.review:
I know what you are thinking. If I have literally all of the money in the world, why would I need to continue to grind for loot boxes in MacGuffin Quest 2? It's simple, really. Look at all that I have achieved in my life:

[list]
[*]Financial independence at a young age 
[*]Built a successful game development company from the ground up 
[*]Launched an all-time record high IPO 
[*]Named Time Magazine's Person of the Year for five years running (unrelated: I bought Time Magazine years ago)
[/list]

There is really only one thing left to accomplish: Unlocking MacGuffin as a playable character.

38295267.review:

11/10, would end all war and happiness in pursuit of a rare lootbox drop again.

One achievement didn't work properly on release and seems to not work at all since it was fixed in an update.
[strike]I'm sure the dev will get it sorted out.[/strike]

For less than a buck ($1USD), it's a mostly fun distraction.
If you're looking for video game stocking stuffers, consider Loot Box Quest.

I like how ironic the game is, you start of as someone who cares for games and dislikes transactions and eventually as the game continues, you slowly become the thing you hate. There are almost no idle games that have a story, so it's nice to see one that does. Overall the game isn't that bad and the music not being the same track over and over as there are at least four different music soundtracks makes this a game worth buying.

The only problems I can think of would be that there's no x100 for the Game Studio jobs and that it's possible to miss the release X amount of games achievements.
